unit.title: Listening & Speaking II: Storytelling, Debate, and Pronunciation
unit.overview: Learners strengthen oral communication through Ghanaian storytelling, respectful debate, and a British English pronunciation lab (word stress, connected speech). Lessons are short to avoid fatigue and include audio tasks, AI feedback, and XP hooks. Moral focus: speak truth in love; listen with respect.
competencies: Plan and tell a short story with clear beginning, middle, and end.
Use voice features (pace, volume, intonation) and correct word stress to improve clarity.
Participate in a short debate using claims, reasons, and evidence with respectful language.
Listen for key ideas and supporting details in short speeches and summarise accurately.
Deliver a 45–60 second presentation with clear structure and polite register.
values_morals: Respectful dialogue; humility in disagreement; truthfulness in claims.
Proverbs 15:1 – A gentle answer turns away wrath.

lessons.title: Storytelling Techniques (Ghanaian Context)
objectives: Use story structure (beginning–middle–end) with a clear theme or lesson.
Apply dialogue tags and descriptive details to bring scenes to life.

vocabulary.definition: How fast or slow a story moves.
Words that tell who is speaking and how (e.g., 'he whispered').

lessons.moral_link: Use stories to teach wisdom and encourage good character.

content_blocks.body: Plan with a story map: setting → problem → rising action → solution → lesson.
Keep dialogue short and clear; use actions and gestures to show feelings.

ai_task.prompt: Write a 6–8 sentence story outline (bullets) set in your community with a moral lesson.

speaking_task.prompt: Record a 45-second story based on your outline. Use dialogue and a clear moral.

lessons.title: Pronunciation Lab: Word Stress & Intonation (British)
objectives: Identify stressed syllables in common words and pronounce them clearly.
Use rising and falling intonation patterns to show questions and statements.

vocabulary.definition: The emphasis placed on a syllable in a word.
The rise and fall of the voice when speaking.
The weak vowel sound /ə/ in unstressed syllables (e.g., 'teacher' /ˈtiːtʃə/).

lessons.moral_link: Clarity honours your listener; speak so others can understand.

content_blocks.body: Stress examples (British): TA‑ble, TEA‑cher, in‑FOR‑ma‑tion. Intonation: rising for yes/no questions; falling for statements.

speaking_task.prompt: Record yourself reading three sentences: one statement, one yes/no question, one wh‑question. Focus on intonation.

lessons.title: Respectful Debate: Claims, Reasons, Evidence
objectives: State a clear claim and support it with reasons and evidence.
Use respectful language for agreement and disagreement.

vocabulary.definition: A statement that can be argued for or against.
Facts or examples supporting a claim.
An argument opposed to your claim.

lessons.moral_link: Speak the truth in love; listen before you answer.

content_blocks.body: Sentence frames: 'I agree because…', 'I see your point; however…', 'A better reason is…'

content_blocks.caption: Debate cue cards for polite language.

classify.prompt: Identify each as Claim (C), Reason (R), or Evidence (E).

items.text: In a 2023 survey, members read 20% more books.
items.label: E

ai_task.prompt: Write a 3‑turn mini‑debate: your claim, a counter‑argument, and your reply using polite language.

lessons.title: Listening Comprehension: Short Speech
objectives: Listen for main idea, key details, and speaker’s tone.
Take brief notes and summarise in 2–3 sentences.

vocabulary.definition: Writing short points to remember information.

lessons.moral_link: Good listening shows respect and leads to understanding.

content_blocks.body: Listen twice if possible: first for main idea, second for details.

comprehension.q: What is the main idea of the speech?
options: Encouraging a school clean‑up campaign with clear steps.

comprehension.q: Which detail supports the main idea?
options: The date and time for the clean‑up.
The price of a broom in town.

summary_task.prompt: Write a 2–3 sentence summary including the main idea and two key details.

lessons.title: Presentation Skills: Speak with Confidence
objectives: Organise a 45–60 second presentation with clear opening, points, and closing.
Use eye contact, posture, and voice control to enhance delivery.

vocabulary.definition: How you hold your body when standing or sitting.
Sending your voice clearly so the audience can hear.

lessons.moral_link: Confidence grows with practice; encourage others as you speak.

content_blocks.body: Use a simple outline: greeting → main idea → two points with examples → conclusion with call to action.

ai_task.prompt: Draft a 4‑point outline for a 60‑second talk encouraging classmates to read daily.

speaking_task.prompt: Record your 45–60 second presentation using your outline. Focus on posture and voice.

quiz_mcq.q: In British English, the stressed syllable in 'information' is:

options: I see your point; however, the data suggest a different result.

quiz_mcq.q: Listening for key details helps you:

options: A greeting, two clear points with examples, and a closing.

speaking_task.prompt: Deliver a 45–60 second persuasive talk on a school improvement idea (e.g., reading club, cleanliness). Use respectful language and clear structure.

criteria.name: Delivery
criteria.descriptor: Audible volume, steady pace, appropriate intonation.

criteria.name: Language
criteria.descriptor: Polite register; accurate pronunciation and word stress.

criteria.name: Engagement
criteria.descriptor: Eye contact (camera), posture, and call to action.
